ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .

The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

Instructor: Tamar Makov  Lisa Veliz

Instructor: Tamar Makov  Tamar was a great TA. The LCA work session were a bit rough around the edges but I appreciate Tamar's frankness. I also am really so into her line of research so I value everything she's taught me about food and life cycle assessment work.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Tamar Makov  We were confused and hit many low points with our project and wished we received more guidance. We asked for help but it seemed like she didn't read our material prior to meeting with us.

Instructor: Tamar Makov  Can be pretty dismissive of people's questions and ideas. Not very accessible in terms of asking questions about the project or assignments. Doesn't seem very committed to being a good TA and answering questions

Instructor: Tamar Makov  She was unapproachable and not constructive in her feedback. I do not understand why she was assigned as a TA for this course when it was very evident that she was not interested in providing help to the students. In giving feedback for the final projects, she simply gave criticism and did not follow up with the groups when asked to see that solutions could be met.
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Although I am an auditor, Tamar went out of her way to offer me guidance and feedback on the limited number of assignments I was responsible for. Fantastic job.

Instructor: Tamar Makov  I do not know the TA well enough, nor did I interact frequently enough to provide accurate feedback. The TA was present during lecture and responded promptly to requests by others.

Instructor: Tamar Makov  She was extremely critical, condescending, with a superiority complex unlike anything I have seen at Yale. She thinks she knows everything about everything and you can never convince her she is not right.
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Teaching assistants were helpful with assignments and homework.

Instructor: Tamar Makov  The teaching assistant provided helpful feedback and was available when needed. She also graded fairly. While the teaching assistant only led one discussion, it would have been valuable to have her lead more sections/lectures that she is passionate and/or knowledgeable about.
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Not approachable, stubborn.
Instructor: Tamar Makov  They didn't participate much in class, but did do grading of assignments and provide feedback. Feedback could be tough
Instructor: Tamar Makov  Aggressive attitude and not clear in project feedback.
Instructor: Tamar Makov  I thought that Tamar's lecture on the IE of food production was very informative and that she answered students' questions effectively.

Instructor: Tamar Makov  Tamar was helpful for our group project, though we didn't interact with her frequently. She wasn't particularly engaged with the class outside of the grading and the two lectures she guest taught, it would have been nice to have more interaction with her through the class (office hours if needed, etc.).
Instructor: Tamar Makov  grading methodology not always clear not responsive to some emails

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I like the subject of industrial ecology and was excited to take this introductory course. However, I was very disappointed with the structure of the projects. The project was not clear from the start, the identified clients fell through mid-way, and we were not able to start substantial work until the last month. We did not receive much guidance even though we asked. Everything else about the course was great but the project was very very disappointing.

The course content needs to be revised, updated and made relevant to the present world and expectations of the student. The IE course was too theoretical when IE is not theoretical at all. It would have been great if we would have discussed how to apply IE to different industrial sectors through each week of the course instead of just going over the theory repeatedly again and again throughout the course. The course was a literal waste of time. I have come out learning almost nothing from this course.

I was very disappointed in this course. I did not feel that the lectures formed a coherent course and did not tie in very theoretical concepts to practical applications. The final projects were poorly structured and the contacts and teaching staff assigned did not offer much to enable the students to produce meaningful work.

I only gave Question 14 a rating of 2 because I'm an auditor. I am certain that with the group project and more assignments I could attest to this course being a 1. This rating assumes we are to look at the rating scale in absolute terms.

Question 1: Some of the readings were very interesting conceptually and theoretically. It would have been nice to spend a little more time in class discussing some of these concepts/theories before jumping into examples of direct application.
Pace of class was too slow. No reinforcement of readings, eliminating any motivation to do them (besides personal interest).

I don't think the final project proposals were developed enough. Our client clearly had ideas that directly conflicted with the professor's ideas. As a result, our grade and understanding of the material seriously suffered.

Question 2: I felt that there were way too many different assignments in this class. Rather than having debates, weekly readings, reading responses, client projects, problem sets, and a midterm, the course would have felt less chaotic by choosing only a few types of assignments and having multiple iterations of them (i.e. having only problem sets instead of reading responses or having another debate instead of the midterm). Because the assignments were so different, they were not very deep and I didn't feel like I got very much out of them. The assignments also had Question 3: I did not feel like the readings were integrated well into class at all. It didn't seem necessary to even do the readings in most lectures. Perhaps the readings could be made optional to help adjust the focus of the workload.

Tom is an expert in the space and it was great to have exposure to him and the high level concepts of industrial ecology. However, I recommend that this class is co-taught between two people with different focus areas in the future. Tom's focus is metals which became very central to the course, but did not match most students' (including my own's) expectations for what the course would be about and what industrial ecology is. The guest lectures were a helpful way to get additional perspectives on the topic, but I think having Marian Chertow or Reid Lifset (or both) coteach the class in the future would provide a much broader picture of what industrial ecology is and how it can be applicable to different topics. The topics were very interesting, but became somewhat repetitive and didn't match the readings/semester projects very well.

Industrial Ecology is an extremely interesting and important subject. However the instructor made it monotonous by focusing merely on metals and metals cycle during the whole semester and made it extremely boring - to say the least. Majority of people in the class were on their phones or doing other things while in class because the material presented was either repeated over and over or boring. The instructor should have strived for variety and applicability to different sectors and industries. It is known that the instructor's expertise is metals, however the course was not entitled "industrial ecology of metals". Yale is renown for the field of industrial ecology but yet it fails greatly when it comes to teaching this and other subjects. It's about time that Yale starts train professors... and teach them how to teach !!!

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: There weren't very many. While the professor is dedicated to the subject, he doesn't convey the material in a very lively way.
NONE
Lots of IE concepts that I didn't know were helpful to learn and will tie in to portions of my dissertation research.

I enjoyed the final project. It was helpful that I landed on a great team with quality team members. The project topic itself was new and interesting to me. A great overall addition to my experience in the class.
Final project, hands-down.
The professor's lectures were very clear and enjoyable.
The group project was fun. The subject matter was very interesting but could be explained/contextualized better

The professor had very good lecture material and presentation. Earlier in the semester the professor included more class discussion and videos. Continuation of that approach throughout the semester would be beneficial.
Industrial Ecology is an interesting and valuable topic and it was good to get an understanding of what it can and can't do.

I enjoyed having the flexibility to work on a client project although it was challenging at times given the short nature of the project. I thought that my group worked very well together and the project topic was very interesting. I was very happy that the course gave us the opportunity to travel as part of the project work. I felt that the teaching team did a moderately good job of responding to queries from the students.

The best aspects were the final projects, as they provided us with the chance to explore a wide range of topics related to industrial ecology and apply the concepts we learned in many different settings.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Definitely the structure of the project.

Both the teaching and course content need significant improvement. The teaching style this year was very old-school, with straight lecturing and some meager attempts at discussion that mainly resulted in cold-calling. The content was very repetitive, unorganized, and research-heavy. Instead of talking about real-world applications, it was mostly graphs from various research papers. Overall, it just wasn't engaging or informative!
i wish the class were broader and covered more topics other than mining and MFAs.

The course content needs to be revised, updated and made relevant to the present world and expectations of the student. The IE course was too theoretical when IE is not theoretical at all. It would have been great if we would have discussed how to apply IE to different industrial sectors through each week of the course instead of just going over the theory repeatedly again and again throughout the course. The course was a literal waste of time. I have come out learning almost nothing from this course.
Lectures, final project.

Too broad of a topic. Unfortunately I didn't take away anything from the course, accept a great team experience. Perhaps my professional experience overlapped too much. This course is great for someone with little or no background in the topics covered in class.
Felt a bit rushed at times and I really didn't appreciate not having as much time for my exam as we should have.

The assignment structure felt a bit disorganized with too many moving pieces. The critical reviews and Part B of the MFA assignment did not contribute to my learning. Similarly, the midterm felt unnecessary. Instead, it would have been nice to spend more time preparing for the final project, learning new skills, delving deeper into some of the course materials, etc.
Making classes more engaging. Sometimes it was easy to stop listening
Pace of class needs to increase two-fold. Readings should be discussed in class.
Lectures weren't very engaging.

The midterm did not advance my knowledge of the subject material at all and I did not feel like it served a very effective purpose in the course. Some of the material on the midterm was not very useful from a practical standpoint, like the first question on the product flow. I also felt that since the material we covered in the course was so broad, it would make more sense for there to have been multiple questions and for students to choose a selection of those questions to answer. We all come from very different backgrounds and have different IE interests, so I think it would be more useful if we could write/answer the things we are most engaged with. Since we had a final project, it just didn't make much sense to me to have a tests. In addition, we were only tested on material from half of the semester since there was no final exam, so the material in the last half of the course was not focused on as much. I thought that the prompts for the debates were not very open-ended and in many cases the readings for that week primarily displayed only one side of an argument. The material focused very heavily on metals although I know that IE is much broader than that. I liked the guest lectures a lot and I think more of them would have been very beneficial to expanding the breadth of the course.

I think that the lectures themselves and the HW assignments could use some improvement- lectures became extremely repetitive and somewhat boring after some time, and the homework assignments (particularly the critical reviews) seemed more like busy work than actual work that was helping us learn more about industrial ecology.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: The course content needs to be revised, updated and made relevant to the present world and expectations of the student. The IE course was too theoretical when IE is not theoretical at all. It would have been great if we would have discussed how to apply IE to different industrial sectors through each week of the course instead of just going over the theory repeatedly again and again throughout the course. The course was a literal waste of time. I have come out learning almost nothing from this course.

Course lectures tied into discussions. However, I feel that cold calling creates an atmosphere that prioritizes a few voices in the class and actually deters the majority of students from having a meaningful discussion. During some class sessions, it would be nice to break into smaller groups to thoroughly discuss the material. In smaller groups everyone would have an opportunity to speak and would likely feel more comfortable doing so.
N/A
no

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: i'm interested in CSR and feel that this class has great potential to be useful especially with more case studies.
The course is completely irrelevant and probably meant for high school student or probably not even for them. It's too kiddish.
Very closely related to some of my research.
I hope to concentrate in IE so it's necessary

The course provided a solid overview of the field of industrial ecology. My interests lie in understanding environmental challenges in cities. I believe that exposure to the industrial ecology framework has provided me with another lens through which to view these challenges.
Looking at the IE and Green Design specialization

I took this course because I am concentrating in Industrial Ecology but I still do not feel like I have a full grasp of what IE stands for and the direction in which the field will be going in the future.

This course is very relevant to my focus areas of business and the environment and industrial ecology, and my current summer internship in the circular economy space. I think having it on my transcript and understanding the basics of the space will be very useful moving forward, I just wish we had received education on more non-metals focused aspects of industrial ecology over the course of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Because I am focusing on the IE concentration.
I wanted to learn how is IE implemented in the industry but learnt almost nothing.
Opportunity to hear from and learn from Prof. Graedel, plus add more value to my knowledge of IE concepts. Course delivered on those fronts.

I thought this course would help provide more context for systems analysis thinking, and supply-chain management. I was looking for a window into the world of closed loop cycles, the circular economy, and the state of industrial ecology today.
To gain a theoretical and practical exposure to Industrial Ecology and to incorporate the concepts in my research.
IE specialization
To learn the methodologies used in the industrial ecology practice.
I am concentrating in IE and wanted to take this foundational course.
See above, wanted to gain a deeper understanding of this space as its relevant to my future career plans.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Not really. I couldn't not take this course, but it was very repetitive and so broad.
No. I didn't learn much, except for MFA, and what I did learn, I'm not sure how to implement in the real world.
no it didn't unfortunately
NO WAY!
Not at all. There should have been more emphasis on practical applications of industrial ecology rather than lectures on broad theories.
Yes.
Largely yes.
Somewhat. Some of the material was a little too much of a general overview, and I would have liked to receive more practice with IE methodologies.
Maybe more practical skills with actual IE tools would have been great
The knowledge/skills that you gained from the course met my expectations.
Below expectations, mostly due to the slow pace. Much more depth could have been covered.

Somewhat, decent overview of broad concepts of industrial ecology, but too metals focused, not very practical. Could have benefitted from a wider range of examples, case studies, more practical application focused lectures.
Absolutely not

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The project was not structured in the beginning and that set the tone for the rest of the semester and it was very disappointing.

The group project was a poor fit for this class- the topics were too massive for a 10 week class. They were more like something a PhD student might work on for several years, not a group project for several weeks. It was very difficult to get data, and we ended up extrapolating results from basically three data points. Commitment to the group work varied considerably- half of our team was pretty uninterested in the work and in doing their fair share. Overall, a lot of work, not sure what I learned, and I don't feel like it could have been properly accomplished in the amount of time that we had. Also- the spring break deadline was very inappropriate!
learned from teammates, dove in depth on 1 project

Regular group work. There was no advantage of the connections the TA or the professor had arranged. There was almost no data available with these contacts. I think, the TAs or the professor should make sure that the organization students are connected with are willing to entertain students, their queries and data requests instead of making students a shuttle cock to be thrown from one department to another.
The group work was a very negative experience and did not result in a productive work environment. The course did not do a good job of engaging students in the subject and work at hand.
Worked on a project that was useful and valuable to outside stakeholders. I would like to have more time for projects of this nature. Perhaps it could be assigned earlier in the term.
Organization is always trying. I was extraordinarily lucky because my ground really jelled well.

Advantages: Learning from teammates and building collaboration skills. Disadvantages: In a team, people do what they are most comfortable with. Therefore, often times, I feel that I don't learn as much in a team setting when compared to working on individual projects.
The group work was an excellent part of this course and a huge part of the learning.

Group work for the class final project seems very appropriate for the course. Group work allows teams to achieve much more within the project time frame and to draw from different team members strengths and experiences. A disadvantage, as with all group work, is the possibility of not having a strong work dynamic among group members.

I had a wonderful group who made themselves available to work and were very helpful from start to finish in all aspects of the project. The project and working with my group members was one of the highlights of the course

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Consider if you know this material already (it can be pretty basic and common knowledge). Consider who is teaching the course this year versus in coming/past years, because it will very widely based on the professor. Overall, keep your expectations low.
it's probably better with Marian teaching it even though Tom is a sweetheart.
Don't take this course if you know even a little about IE. Read 2-3 papers and you would have learned the same thing as is delivered in this course.
I would not recommend taking this course.

If you have previous knowledge of systems thinking, supply-chain, the circular economy, sharing economy etc...this course might not be challenging enough, and the work less valuable to your experience at FES. The course appeared to be driven by a need to prove the field of study as legitimate, rather than to provide any real take-away that could be immediately useful.
Really prioritize what can be achieved during the very short timeline designated for final projects.
The readings are very interesting, the lectures can be boring, and you learn from the assignments (but not so much soft skills)
If Prof. Chertow is teaching it, then go for it; her guest lectures were among the highlights of the class.
Choosing the right group project can really change the outlook of your semester. Overall, I think there are other courses that better encapsulate the ideas surrounding IE.

This course really depends on who's teaching it, so only sign up if your interests align with that of the instructor. However, regardless of the instructor this course will give you a good broad overview of industrial ecology.
